Agnostic Federated Learning

Abstract

A key learning scenario in large-scale applications is that of federated learning, where a centralized model is trained based on data originating from a large number of clients. We argue that, with the existing training and inference, federated models can be biased towards different clients. Instead, we propose a new framework of agnostic federated learning, where the centralized model is optimized for any target distribution formed by a mixture of the client distributions. We further show that this framework naturally yields a notion of fairness. We present data-dependent Rademacher complexity guarantees for learning with this objective, which guide the definition of an algorithm for agnostic federated learning. We also give a fast stochastic optimization algorithm for solving the corresponding optimization problem, for which we prove convergence bounds, assuming a convex loss function and hypothesis set. We further empirically demonstrate the benefits of our approach in several datasets. Beyond federated learning, our framework and algorithm can be of interest to other learning scenarios such as cloud computing, domain adaptation, drifting, and other contexts where the training and test distributions do not coincide.

1 Motivation

A key learning scenario in large-scale applications is that of federated learning. In that scenario, a centralized model is trained based on data originating from a large number of clients, which may be mobile phones, other mobile devices, or sensors (Konečnỳ, McMahan, Yu, Richtárik, Suresh, and Bacon, 2016b, a). The training data typically remains distributed over the clients, each with possibly unreliable or relatively slow network connections.

Federated learning raises several types of issues and has been the topic of multiple research efforts. These include systems, networking and communication bottleneck problems due to frequent exchanges between the central server and the clients . To deal with such problems, McMahan et al. (2017) suggested an averaging technique that consists of transmitting the central model to a subset of clients, training it with the data locally available, and averaging the local updates. Smith et al. (2017) proposed to further leverage the relationship between clients, assumed to be known, and cast the problem as an instance of multi-task learning to derive local client models benefiting from other similar ones.

The optimization task in federated learning, which is a principal problem in this scenario, has also been the topic of multiple research work. That includes the design of more efficient communication strategies (Konečnỳ, McMahan, Yu, Richtárik, Suresh, and Bacon, 2016b, a; Suresh, Yu, Kumar, and McMahan, 2017), devising efficient distributed optimization methods benefiting from differential privacy guarantees (Agarwal, Suresh, Yu, Kumar, and McMahan, 2018), as well as recent guarantees for parallel stochastic optimization with a dependency graph (Woodworth, Wang, Smith, McMahan, and Srebro, 2018).

Another key problem in federated learning which appears more generally in distributed machine learning and other learning setups is that of fairness. In many instances in practice, the resulting learning models may be biased or unfair: they may discriminate against some protected groups (Bickel, Hammel, and O’Connell, 1975; Hardt, Price, Srebro, et al., 2016). As a simple example, a regression algorithm predicting a person’s salary could be using that person’s gender. This is a key problem in modern machine learning that does not seem to have been specifically studied in the context of federated learning.

While many problems related to federated learning have been extensively studied, the key objective of learning in that context seems not to have been carefully examined. We are also not aware of statistical guarantees derived for learning in this scenario. A crucial reason for such questions to emerge in this context is that the target distribution for which the centralized model is learned is unspecified. Which expected loss is federated learning seeking to minimize? Most centralized models for standard federated learning are trained on the aggregate training sample obtained from the subsamples drawn from the clients. Thus, if we denote by 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k} the distribution associated to client k𝑘k, mksubscript𝑚𝑘m_{k} the size of the sample available from that client and m𝑚m the total sample size, intrinsically, the centralized model is trained to minimize the loss with respect to the uniform distribution

𝒰¯=∑k=1pmkm​𝒟k.¯𝒰superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝑚𝑘𝑚subscript𝒟𝑘\overline{\mathscr{U}}=\textstyle\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{m_{k}}{m}{\mathscr{D}}_{k}.

But why should 𝒰¯¯𝒰\overline{\mathscr{U}} be the target distribution of the learning model? Is 𝒰¯¯𝒰\overline{\mathscr{U}} the distribution that we expect to observe at test time? What guarantees can be derived for the deployed system?

Notice that, in practice, in federated learning, the probability that an individual data source participates in training depends on various factors such as whether the mobile device is connected to the internet or whether it is being charged. Thus, the training data may not truly reflect the usage of the learned model in inference. Additionally, these uncertainties may also affect the size of the sample mksubscript𝑚𝑘m_{k} acquired from each client, which directly affects the definition of 𝒰¯¯𝒰\overline{\mathscr{U}}.

We argue that in many common instances, the uniform distribution is not the natural objective distribution and that seeking to minimize the expected loss with respect to the specific distribution 𝒰¯¯𝒰\overline{\mathscr{U}} is risky. This is because the target distribution may be in general quite different from 𝒰¯¯𝒰\overline{\mathscr{U}}. In many cases, that can result in a suboptimal or even a detrimental performance. For example, imagine a plausible scenario of federated learning where the learner has access to a large population of expensive mobile phones, which are most commonly adopted by software engineers or other technical users (say 70%percent7070\%) than other users (30%percent3030\%), and a small population of other mobile phones less used by non-technical users (5%percent55\%) and significantly more often by other users (95%percent9595\%). The centralized model would then be essentially based on the uniform distribution based on the expensive clients. But, clearly, such a model would not be adapted to the wide general target domain formed by the majority of phones with a 5%​-​95%percent5percent955\%\mathord{-}95\% population of general versus technical users. Many other realistic examples of this type can help illustrate the learning problem resulting from a mismatch between the target distribution and 𝒰¯¯𝒰\overline{\mathscr{U}}. In fact, it is not clear why minimizing the expected loss with respect to 𝒰¯¯𝒰\overline{\mathscr{U}} could be beneficial for the clients, whose distributions are 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k}s.

Thus, we put forward a new framework of agnostic federated learning (AFL), where the centralized model is optimized for any possible target distribution formed by a mixture of the client distributions. Instead of optimizing the centralized model for a specific distribution, with the high risk of a mismatch with the target, we define an agnostic and more risk-averse objective. We show that, for some target mixture distributions, the cross-entropy loss of the hypothesis obtained by minimization with respect to the uniform distribution 𝒰¯¯𝒰\overline{\mathscr{U}} can be worse, by a constant additive term, than that of the hypothesis obtained in AFL, even if the learner has access to an infinite sample size (Section 3.2).

We further show that our AFL framework naturally yields a notion of fairness, which we refer to as good-intent fairness (Section 3.3). Indeed, the predictor solution of the optimization problem for our AFL framework treats all protected categories similarly. Beyond federated learning, our framework and solution also cover related problems in cloud-based learning services, where customers may not have any training data at their disposal or may not be willing to share that data with the cloud. In that case too, the server needs to train a model without access to the training data. Our framework and algorithm can also be of interest to other learning scenarios such as domain adaptation, drifting, and other contexts where the training and test distributions do not coincide.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we give an extensive discussion of related work, including connections with the broad literature of domain adaptation. In Section 3, we give a formal description of the learning scenario of federated learning and the formulation of the problem as AFL. Next, we give a detailed theoretical analysis of learning in the AFL framework, including data-dependent Rademacher complexity generalization bounds (Section 4). These bounds lead to a natural learning algorithm with a regularization term based on a skewness term that we define (Section 5). We also present an efficient convex optimization algorithm for solving the optimization problem defining our algorithm (Section 5.2). Our algorithm is a stochastic gradient-descent solution for minimax problems, for which we give a detailed analysis, including the proof of convergence in terms of the variances of the stochastic gradients. In Section 6, we present a series of experiments comparing our AFL algorithm and solution with existing federated learning solutions. In Section 7, we discuss several extensions of AFL.

2 Related work

Here, we briefly discuss several learning scenarios and work related to our study of federated learning.

The problem of federated learning is closely related to other learning scenarios where there is a mismatch between the source distribution and the target distribution. This includes the problem of transfer learning or domain adaptation from a single source to a known target domain (Ben-David, Blitzer, Crammer, and Pereira, 2006; Mansour, Mohri, and Rostamizadeh, 2009b; Cortes and Mohri, 2014; Cortes, Mohri, and Muñoz Medina, 2015), either through unsupervised adaptation techniques (Gong et al., 2012; Long et al., 2015; Ganin and Lempitsky, 2015; Tzeng et al., 2015), or via lightly supervised ones (some amount of labeled data from the target domain) (Saenko et al., 2010; Yang et al., 2007; Hoffman et al., 2013; Girshick et al., 2014). This also includes previous applications in natural language processing (Dredze et al., 2007; Blitzer et al., 2007; Jiang and Zhai, 2007; Raju et al., 2018), speech recognition (Legetter and Woodland, 1995; Gauvain and Chin-Hui, 1994; Pietra et al., 1992; Rosenfeld, 1996; Jelinek, 1998; Roark and Bacchiani, 2003), and computer vision (Martínez, 2002)

A problem more closely related to that of federated learning is that of multiple-source adaptation, first formalized and analyzed theoretically by Mansour, Mohri, and Rostamizadeh (2009c, a) and later studied for various applications such as object recognition (Hoffman et al., 2012; Gong et al., 2013a, b). Recently, Zhang et al. (2015) studied a causal formulation of this problem for a classification scenario, using the same combination rules as Mansour et al. (2009c, a). The problem of domain generalization (Pan and Yang, 2010; Muandet et al., 2013; Xu et al., 2014), where knowledge from an arbitrary number of related domains is combined to perform well on a previously unseen domain is very closely related to that of federated learning, though the assumptions about the information available to the learner and the availability of unlabeled data may differ.

In the multiple-source adaptation problem studied by Mansour, Mohri, and Rostamizadeh (2009c, a) and Hoffman, Mohri, and Zhang (2018), each domain k𝑘k is defined by the corresponding distribution 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k} and the learner has only access to a predictor hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} for each domain and no access to labeled training data drawn from these domains. The authors show that it is possible to define a predictor hℎh whose expected loss ℒ𝒟​(h)subscriptℒ𝒟ℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{\mathscr{D}}(h) with respect to any distribution 𝒟𝒟{\mathscr{D}} that is a mixture of the source domains 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k} is at most the maximum expected loss of the source predictors: maxk⁡L𝒟k​(h𝒟k)subscript𝑘subscript𝐿subscript𝒟𝑘subscriptℎsubscript𝒟𝑘\max_{k}L_{{\mathscr{D}}_{k}}(h_{{\mathscr{D}}_{k}}). They also provide an algorithm for determining hℎh.

Our learning scenario differs from the one adopted in that work since we assume access to labeled training data from each domain 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k}. Furthermore, the predictor determined by the algorithm of Hoffman, Mohri, and Zhang (2018) belongs to a specific hypothesis set ℋ′superscriptℋ′{\mathscr{H}}^{\prime}, which is that of distribution weighted combinations of the domain predictors hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k}, while, in our setup, the objective is to determine the best predictor in some global hypothesis set ℋℋ{\mathscr{H}}, which may include ℋ′superscriptℋ′{\mathscr{H}}^{\prime} as a subset, and which is not depending on some domain-specific predictors.

Our optimization solution also differs from the work of Farnia and Tse (2016) and Lee and Raginsky (2017) on local minimax results, where samples are drawn from a single source 𝒟𝒟{\mathscr{D}}, and where the generalization error is minimized over a set of locally ambiguous distributions 𝒟^^𝒟\widehat{\mathscr{D}}, where 𝒟^^𝒟\widehat{\mathscr{D}} is the empirical distribution. The authors propose this metric for statistical robustness. In our work, we obtain samples from p𝑝p unknown distributions, and the set of distributions Dλsubscript𝐷𝜆D_{\lambda} over which we optimize the expected loss is fixed and independent of samples. Furthermore, the source distributions can differ arbitrarily and need not be close to each other. In reverse, we note that our stochastic algorithm can be used to minimize the loss functions proposed in (Farnia and Tse, 2016; Lee and Raginsky, 2017).

3 Learning scenario

In this section, we introduce the learning scenario of agnostic federated learning we consider. Next, we first argue that the uniform solution commonly adopted in standard federated learning may not be an adequate solution, thereby further justifying our agnostic model. Second, we show the benefit of our model in fairness learning.

We start with some general notation and definitions used throughout the paper. Let 𝒳𝒳{\mathscr{X}} denote the input space and 𝒴𝒴{\mathscr{Y}} the output space. We will primarily discuss a multi-class classification problem where 𝒴𝒴{\mathscr{Y}} is a finite set of classes, but much of our results can be extended straightforwardly to regression and other problems. The hypotheses we consider are of the form h:𝒳→Δ𝒴:ℎ→𝒳subscriptΔ𝒴h\colon{\mathscr{X}}\to\Delta_{\mathscr{Y}}, where Δ𝒴subscriptΔ𝒴\Delta_{\mathscr{Y}} stands for the simplex over 𝒴𝒴{\mathscr{Y}}. Thus, h​(x)ℎ𝑥h(x) is a probability distribution over the classes or categories that can be assigned to x∈𝒳𝑥𝒳x\in{\mathscr{X}}. We will denote by ℋℋ{\mathscr{H}} a family of such hypotheses hℎh. We also denote by ℓℓ\ell a loss function defined over Δ𝒴×𝒴subscriptΔ𝒴𝒴\Delta_{\mathscr{Y}}\times{\mathscr{Y}} and taking non-negative values. The loss of h∈ℋℎℋh\in{\mathscr{H}} for a labeled sample (x,y)∈𝒳×𝒴𝑥𝑦𝒳𝒴(x,y)\in{\mathscr{X}}\times{\mathscr{Y}} is given by ℓ​(h​(x),y)ℓℎ𝑥𝑦\ell(h(x),y). One key example in applications is the cross-entropy loss, which is defined as follows: ℓ​(h​(x),y)=−log⁡(ℙy′∼h​(x)[y′=y])ℓℎ𝑥𝑦subscriptℙsimilar-tosuperscript𝑦′ℎ𝑥superscript𝑦′𝑦\ell(h(x),y)=-\log(\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{y^{\prime}\sim h(x)}[y^{\prime}=y]). We will denote by ℒ𝒟​(h)subscriptℒ𝒟ℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{\mathscr{D}}(h) the expected loss of a hypothesis hℎh with respect to a distribution 𝒟𝒟{\mathscr{D}} over 𝒳×𝒴𝒳𝒴{\mathscr{X}}\times{\mathscr{Y}}:

ℒ𝒟​(h)=𝔼(x,y)∼𝒟[ℓ​(h​(x),y)],subscriptℒ𝒟ℎsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑥𝑦𝒟ℓℎ𝑥𝑦{\mathscr{L}}_{\mathscr{D}}(h)=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{(x,y)\sim{\mathscr{D}}}[\ell(h(x),y)],

and by h𝒟subscriptℎ𝒟h_{\mathscr{D}} its minimizer: h𝒟=argminh∈ℋℒ𝒟​(h)subscriptℎ𝒟subscriptargminℎℋsubscriptℒ𝒟ℎh_{\mathscr{D}}=\operatorname*{argmin}_{h\in{\mathscr{H}}}{\mathscr{L}}_{\mathscr{D}}(h).

3.1 Agnostic federated learning

We consider a learning scenario where the learner receives p𝑝p samples S1,…,Spsubscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑝S_{1},\ldots,S_{p}, with each Sk=((xk,1,yk,1),…,(xk,mk,yk,mk))∈(𝒳×𝒴)mksubscript𝑆𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘1subscript𝑦𝑘1…subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘superscript𝒳𝒴subscript𝑚𝑘S_{k}=((x_{k,1},y_{k,1}),\ldots,(x_{k,m_{k}},y_{k,m_{k}}))\in({\mathscr{X}}\times{\mathscr{Y}})^{m_{k}} of size mksubscript𝑚𝑘m_{k} drawn i.i.d. from a different domain or distribution 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k}. The learner’s objective is to determine a hypothesis h∈ℋℎℋh\in{\mathscr{H}} that performs well on some target distribution. We will also denote by 𝒟^ksubscript^𝒟𝑘\widehat{\mathscr{D}}_{k} the empirical distribution associated to sample Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} of size m𝑚m drawn from 𝒟msuperscript𝒟𝑚{\mathscr{D}}^{m}.

This scenario coincides with that of federated learning where training is done with the uniform distribution over the union of all samples Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k}, that is 𝒰^=∑k=1pmk∑k=1pmk​𝒟^k^𝒰superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝑚𝑘subscript^𝒟𝑘\widehat{\mathscr{U}}=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{m_{k}}{\sum_{k=1}^{p}m_{k}}\widehat{\mathscr{D}}_{k}, and where the underlying assumption is that the target distribution is 𝒰¯=∑k=1pmk∑k=1pmk​𝒟k¯𝒰superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝑚𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘\overline{\mathscr{U}}=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{m_{k}}{\sum_{k=1}^{p}m_{k}}{\mathscr{D}}_{k}. We will not adopt that assumption since it is rather restrictive and since, as discussed later, it can lead to solutions that are disadvantageous to domain users. Instead, we will consider an agnostic federated learning (AFL) scenario where the target distribution can be modeled as an unknown mixture of the distributions 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k}, k=1,…,p𝑘1…𝑝k=1,\ldots,p, that is 𝒟λ=∑k=1pλk​𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\lambda_{k}{\mathscr{D}}_{k} for some λ∈Δp𝜆subscriptΔ𝑝\lambda\in\Delta_{p}. Since the mixture weight λ𝜆\lambda is unknown, here, the learner must come up with a solution that is favorable for any λ𝜆\lambda in the simplex, or any λ𝜆\lambda in a subset Λ⊆ΔpΛsubscriptΔ𝑝\Lambda\subseteq\Delta_{p}. Thus, we define the agnostic loss (or agnostic risk) ℒ𝒟Λ​(h)subscriptℒsubscript𝒟Λℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h) associated to a predictor h∈ℋℎℋh\in{\mathscr{H}} as

ℒ𝒟Λ​(h)=maxλ∈Λ⁡ℒ𝒟λ​(h).subscriptℒsubscript𝒟Λℎsubscript𝜆Λsubscriptℒsubscript𝒟𝜆ℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h)=\max_{\lambda\in\Lambda}{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h). (1)

We will extend our previous definitions and denote by h𝒟Λsubscriptℎsubscript𝒟Λh_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}} the minimizer of this loss:

h𝒟Λ=argminh∈ℋℒ𝒟Λ​(h).subscriptℎsubscript𝒟Λsubscriptargminℎℋsubscriptℒsubscript𝒟Λℎh_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}=\operatorname*{argmin}_{h\in{\mathscr{H}}}{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h).

In practice, the learner has access to the distributions 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k} only via the finite samples Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k}. Thus, for any λ∈Δp𝜆subscriptΔ𝑝\lambda\in\Delta_{p}, instead of the mixture 𝒟λsubscript𝒟𝜆{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}, only the λ𝜆\lambda-mixture of empirical distributions, 𝒟¯λ=∑k=1pλk​𝒟^ksubscript¯𝒟𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝜆𝑘subscript^𝒟𝑘\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\lambda_{k}\widehat{\mathscr{D}}_{k}, is accessible.111Note, 𝒟¯λsubscript¯𝒟𝜆\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda} is distinct from an empirical distribution 𝒟^λsubscript^𝒟𝜆\widehat{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda} which would be based on a sample drawn from 𝒟λsubscript𝒟𝜆{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}. 𝒟¯λsubscript¯𝒟𝜆\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda} is based on samples drawn from 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k}s. This leads to the definition of ℒ𝒟¯Λ​(h)subscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟Λℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h), the agnostic empirical loss of a hypothesis h∈ℋℎℋh\in{\mathscr{H}} for a subset of the simplex ΛΛ\Lambda:

ℒ𝒟¯Λ​(h)=maxλ∈Λ⁡ℒ𝒟¯λ​(h).subscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟Λℎsubscript𝜆Λsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟𝜆ℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h)=\max_{\lambda\in\Lambda}{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h).

We will denote by h𝒟¯Λsubscriptℎsubscript¯𝒟Λh_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}} the minimizer of this loss: h𝒟¯Λ=argminh∈ℋℒ𝒟¯Λ​(h)subscriptℎsubscript¯𝒟Λsubscriptargminℎℋsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟Λℎh_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}=\operatorname*{argmin}_{h\in\mathcal{H}}{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h). In the next section, we will present generalization bounds relating the expected and empirical agnostic losses ℒ𝒟Λ​(h)subscriptℒsubscript𝒟Λℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h) and ℒ𝒟¯Λ​(h)subscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟Λℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h) for all h∈ℋℎℋh\in{\mathscr{H}}.

Notice that the domains 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k} discussed thus far need not coincide with the clients. In fact, when the number of clients is very large and ΛΛ\Lambda is the full simplex, Λ=ΔpΛsubscriptΔ𝑝\Lambda=\Delta_{p}, it is typically preferable to consider instead domains defined by clusters of clients, as discussed in Section 7. On the other hand, if p𝑝p is small or ΛΛ\Lambda more restrictive, then the model may not perform well on certain domains of interest. We mitigate the effect of large p𝑝p values using a suitable regularization term derived from our theory.

3.2 Comparison with federated learning

Here, we further argue that the uniform solution h𝒰¯subscriptℎ¯𝒰h_{\overline{\mathscr{U}}} commonly adopted in federated learning may not provide a satisfactory performance compared with a solution of the agnostic problem. This further motivates our AFL model.

As already discussed, since the target distribution is unknown, the natural method for the learner is to select a hypothesis minimizing the agnostic loss ℒ𝒟Λsubscriptℒsubscript𝒟Λ{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}. Is the predictor minimizing the agnostic loss coinciding with the solution h𝒰^subscriptℎ^𝒰h_{\widehat{\mathscr{U}}} of standard federated learning? How poor can the performance of the standard federated learning be? We first show that the loss of h𝒰^subscriptℎ^𝒰h_{\widehat{\mathscr{U}}} can be higher than that of the optimal loss achieved by h𝒟Λsubscriptℎsubscript𝒟Λh_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}} by a constant loss, even if the number of samples tends to infinity, that is even if the learner has access to the distributions 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k} and uses the predictor h𝒰¯subscriptℎ¯𝒰h_{\overline{\mathscr{U}}}. Similar results are known for universal compression, where the goal is to compress a sequence of random variables without knowledge of the generating distribution (Grünwald, 2007).

Proposition 3.1.

Let ℓℓ\ell be the cross-entropy loss. Then, there exist ΛΛ\Lambda, ℋℋ{\mathscr{H}}, and 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k}, k∈[p]𝑘delimited-[]𝑝k\in[p], such that the following inequality holds:

ℒ𝒟Λ​(h𝒰¯)≥ℒ𝒟Λ​(h𝒟Λ)+log⁡23.subscriptℒsubscript𝒟Λsubscriptℎ¯𝒰subscriptℒsubscript𝒟Λsubscriptℎsubscript𝒟Λ23{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h_{\overline{\mathscr{U}}})\geq{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}})+\log\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}.
Proof 3.2.

Consider the following two distributions with support reduced to a single element x∈𝒳𝑥𝒳x\in{\mathscr{X}} and two classes 𝒴={0,1}𝒴01{\mathscr{Y}}=\{0,1\}: 𝒟1​(x,0)=0subscript𝒟1𝑥00{\mathscr{D}}_{1}(x,0)=0, 𝒟2​(x,1)=1subscript𝒟2𝑥11{\mathscr{D}}_{2}(x,1)=1, 𝒟2​(x,0)=12subscript𝒟2𝑥012{\mathscr{D}}_{2}(x,0)=\frac{1}{2}, and 𝒟2​(x,1)=12subscript𝒟2𝑥112{\mathscr{D}}_{2}(x,1)=\frac{1}{2}. Let Λ={δ1,δ2}Λsubscript𝛿1subscript𝛿2\Lambda=\{\delta_{1},\delta_{2}\}, where δksubscript𝛿𝑘\delta_{k}, k=1,2𝑘12k=1,2, denotes the Dirac measure on index k𝑘k. We will consider the case where the sample sizes mksubscript𝑚𝑘m_{k} are all equal, that is h𝒰¯=12​(𝒟1+𝒟2)subscriptℎ¯𝒰12subscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2h_{\overline{\mathscr{U}}}=\frac{1}{2}({\mathscr{D}}_{1}+{\mathscr{D}}_{2}). Let p0subscript𝑝0p_{0} denote the probability that hℎh assigns to class 00 and p1subscript𝑝1p_{1} the one it assigns to class 111. Then, the cross-entropy loss of a predictor hℎh can be expressed as follows:

3.3 Good-intent fairness in learning

Here, we further discuss the relationship between our model of AFL and fairness in learning.

Fairness in machine learning has received much attention in recent past (Bickel et al., 1975; Hardt et al., 2016). There is now a broad literature on the topic with a variety of definitions of the notion of fairness. In a typical scenario, there is a protected class c𝑐c among p𝑝p classes c1,c2,…,cpsubscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2…subscript𝑐𝑝c_{1},c_{2},\ldots,c_{p}. While there are many definitions of fairness, the main objective of a fairness algorithm is to reduce bias and ensure that the model is fair to all the p𝑝p protected categories, under some definition of fairness. The most common reasons for bias in machine learning algorithms are training data bias and overfitting bias. We first provide a brief explanation and illustration for both:

  • •

    the training data is biased: consider the regression task, where the goal is to predict the salary of a person based on features such as education, location, age, gender. Let gender be the protected class. If in the training data, there is a consistent discrimination against women irrespective of their education, e.g., their salary is lower, then we can conclude that the training data is inherently biased.

  • •

    the training procedure is biased: consider an image recognition task where the protected category is race. If the model is heavily trained on images based on certain races, then the resulting model will be biased because of over-fitting.

Our model of AFL can help define a notion of good-intent fairness, where we reduce the bias in the training procedure. Furthermore, if training procedure bias exists, it naturally highlights it.

Suppose we are interested in a classification problem and there is a protected feature class c𝑐c, which can be one of p𝑝p values c1,c2,…,cpsubscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2…subscript𝑐𝑝c_{1},c_{2},\ldots,c_{p}. Then, we define 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k} as the conditional distribution with the protected class being cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k}. If 𝒟𝒟{\mathscr{D}} is the true underlying distribution, then

𝒟k​(x,y)=𝒟​(x,y∣c​(x,y)=ck).subscript𝒟𝑘𝑥𝑦𝒟𝑥conditional𝑦𝑐𝑥𝑦subscript𝑐𝑘{\mathscr{D}}_{k}(x,y)={\mathscr{D}}(x,y\mid c(x,y)=c_{k}).

Let Λ={δk:k∈[p]}Λconditional-setsubscript𝛿𝑘𝑘delimited-[]𝑝\Lambda=\{\delta_{k}\colon k\in[p]\} be the collection of Dirac measures over the indices k𝑘k in [p]delimited-[]𝑝[p]. With this definition, we define a good-intent fairness algorithm as one seeking to minimize the agnostic loss ℒ𝒟Λsubscriptℒsubscript𝒟Λ{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}. Thus, the objective of the algorithm is to minimize the maximum loss incurred on any of the underlying protective classes and hence does not overfit the data to any particular model at the cost of others. Furthermore, it does not degrade the performance of the other classes so long as it does not affect the loss of the most-sensitive protected category. We further note that our approach does not reduce bias in the training data and is useful only for mitigating the training procedure bias.

4 Learning bounds

In this section, we present learning guarantees for agnostic federated learning. Let 𝒢𝒢{\mathscr{G}} denote the family of the losses associated to a hypothesis set ℋℋ{\mathscr{H}}: 𝒢={(x,y)↦ℓ​(h​(x),y):h∈ℋ}𝒢conditional-setmaps-to𝑥𝑦ℓℎ𝑥𝑦ℎℋ{\mathscr{G}}=\{(x,y)\mapsto\ell(h(x),y)\colon h\in{\mathscr{H}}\}. ℒ𝒟λ​(h)≤ℒ𝒟¯λ​(h)+𝔼[maxh∈ℋ⁡ℒ𝒟λ​(h)−ℒ𝒟¯λ​(h)]+M​∑k=1pλk22​mk​log⁡|Λϵ|δ.subscriptℒsubscript𝒟𝜆ℎsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟𝜆ℎ𝔼subscriptℎℋsubscriptℒsubscript𝒟𝜆ℎsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟𝜆ℎ𝑀subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘1subscriptsuperscript𝜆2𝑘2subscript𝑚𝑘subscriptΛitalic-ϵ𝛿{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)\leq{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)+\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}\left[\max_{h\in{\mathscr{H}}}{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)-{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)\right]+M\sqrt{\sum^{p}_{k=1}\frac{\lambda^{2}_{k}}{2m_{k}}\log\frac{|\Lambda_{\epsilon}|}{\delta}}.

By definition of ΛϵsubscriptΛitalic-ϵ\Lambda_{\epsilon}, for any λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda, there exists λ′∈Λϵsuperscript𝜆′subscriptΛitalic-ϵ\lambda^{\prime}\in\Lambda_{\epsilon} such that ℒ𝒟λ​(h)≤ℒ𝒟λ′​(h)+M​ϵsubscriptℒsubscript𝒟𝜆ℎsubscriptℒsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝜆′ℎ𝑀italic-ϵ{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)\leq{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}^{\prime}}(h)+M\epsilon. In view of that, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, for any h∈ℋℎℋh\in{\mathscr{H}} and λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda the following holds:

ℒ𝒟λ​(h)≤ℒ𝒟¯λ​(h)+𝔼[maxh∈ℋ⁡ℒ𝒟λ​(h)−ℒ𝒟¯λ​(h)]+M​ϵ+M​∑k=1pλk22​mk​log⁡|Λϵ|δ.subscriptℒsubscript𝒟𝜆ℎsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟𝜆ℎ𝔼subscriptℎℋsubscriptℒsubscript𝒟𝜆ℎsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟𝜆ℎ𝑀italic-ϵ𝑀subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘1subscriptsuperscript𝜆2𝑘2subscript𝑚𝑘subscriptΛitalic-ϵ𝛿{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)\leq{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)+\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}\left[\max_{h\in{\mathscr{H}}}{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)-{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)\right]+M\epsilon+M\sqrt{\sum^{p}_{k=1}\frac{\lambda^{2}_{k}}{2m_{k}}\log\frac{|\Lambda_{\epsilon}|}{\delta}}.

The expectation appearing on the right-hand side can be bounded following standard proofs for Rademacher complexity upper bounds (see for example (Mohri et al., 2018)), leading to

𝔼[maxh∈ℋ⁡ℒ𝒟λ​(h)−ℒ𝒟¯λ​(h)]≤ℜ𝐦​(𝒢,λ).𝔼subscriptℎℋsubscriptℒsubscript𝒟𝜆ℎsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟𝜆ℎsubscriptℜ𝐦𝒢𝜆\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}\left[\max_{h\in{\mathscr{H}}}{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)-{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)\right]\leq{\mathfrak{R}}_{\mathbf{m}}({\mathscr{G}},\lambda).

The sum ∑k=1pλk2mksubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘1subscriptsuperscript𝜆2𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘\sum^{p}_{k=1}\frac{\lambda^{2}_{k}}{m_{k}} can be expressed in terms of the skewness of ΛΛ\Lambda, using the following equalities:

m​∑k=1pλk2mk=∑k=1pλk2mkm=∑k=1pλk2mkm+∑k=1pmkm−2​∑k=1pλk+1=∑k=1p(λk−mkm)2mkm+1=χ2​(λ∥𝐦¯)+1.𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝜆2𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝜆2𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝜆2𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝑚𝑘𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝜆𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘𝑚2subscript𝑚𝑘𝑚1superscript𝜒2conditional𝜆¯𝐦1\displaystyle m\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{\lambda^{2}_{k}}{m_{k}}=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{\lambda^{2}_{k}}{\frac{m_{k}}{m}}=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{\lambda^{2}_{k}}{\frac{m_{k}}{m}}+\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{m_{k}}{m}-2\sum_{k=1}^{p}\lambda_{k}+1=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{(\lambda_{k}-\frac{m_{k}}{m})^{2}}{\frac{m_{k}}{m}}+1=\chi^{2}(\lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}})+1.

This completes the proof.

It can be proven that the skewness parameter appears in a lower bound on the generalization bound. We will include that result in the final version of this paper. The theorem yields immediately upper bounds for agnostic losses by taking the maximum over λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda: for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, for any h∈ℋℎℋh\in{\mathscr{H}},

ℒ𝒟Λ​(h)subscriptℒsubscript𝒟Λℎ\displaystyle{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h) ≤maxλ∈Λ⁡{ℒ𝒟¯λ​(h)+2​ℜ𝐦​(𝒢,λ)+M​ϵ+M​𝔰​(λ∥𝐦¯)2​m​log⁡|Λϵ|δ}absentsubscript𝜆Λsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟𝜆ℎ2subscriptℜ𝐦𝒢𝜆𝑀italic-ϵ𝑀𝔰conditional𝜆¯𝐦2𝑚subscriptΛitalic-ϵ𝛿\displaystyle\leq\max_{\lambda\in\Lambda}\left\{{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)+2{\mathfrak{R}}_{\mathbf{m}}({\mathscr{G}},\lambda)+M\epsilon+M\sqrt{\frac{{\mathfrak{s}}(\lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}})}{2m}\log\frac{|\Lambda_{\epsilon}|}{\delta}}\right\}
≤ℒ𝒟¯Λ​(h)+maxλ∈Λ⁡{2​ℜ𝐦​(𝒢,λ)+M​ϵ+M​𝔰​(λ∥𝐦¯)2​m​log⁡|Λϵ|δ}absentsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟Λℎsubscript𝜆Λ2subscriptℜ𝐦𝒢𝜆𝑀italic-ϵ𝑀𝔰conditional𝜆¯𝐦2𝑚subscriptΛitalic-ϵ𝛿\displaystyle\leq{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h)+\max_{\lambda\in\Lambda}\left\{2{\mathfrak{R}}_{\mathbf{m}}({\mathscr{G}},\lambda)+M\epsilon+M\sqrt{\frac{{\mathfrak{s}}(\lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}})}{2m}\log\frac{|\Lambda_{\epsilon}|}{\delta}}\right\}
≤ℒ𝒟¯Λ​(h)+2​ℜ𝐦​(𝒢,Λ)+M​ϵ+M​𝔰​(Λ∥𝐦¯)2​m​log⁡|Λϵ|δ.absentsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟Λℎ2subscriptℜ𝐦𝒢Λ𝑀italic-ϵ𝑀𝔰conditionalΛ¯𝐦2𝑚subscriptΛitalic-ϵ𝛿\displaystyle\leq{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h)+2{\mathfrak{R}}_{\mathbf{m}}({\mathscr{G}},\Lambda)+M\epsilon+M\sqrt{\frac{{\mathfrak{s}}(\Lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}})}{2m}\log\frac{|\Lambda_{\epsilon}|}{\delta}}.

The following result shows that, for a family of functions taking values in {−1,+1}11\{-1,+1\}, the Rademacher complexity ℜ𝐦​(𝒢,Λ)subscriptℜ𝐦𝒢Λ{\mathfrak{R}}_{\mathbf{m}}({\mathscr{G}},\Lambda) can be bounded in terms of the VC-dimension and the skewness of ΛΛ\Lambda.

Lemma 4.3.

Let ℓℓ\ell be a loss function taking values in {−1,+1}11\{-1,+1\} and such that the family of losses 𝒢𝒢{\mathscr{G}} admits VC-dimension d𝑑d. Then, the following upper bound holds for the weighted Rademacher complexity of 𝒢𝒢{\mathscr{G}}:

ℜ𝐦​(𝒢,Λ)≤2​𝔰​(Λ∥𝐦¯)​dm​log⁡[e​md].subscriptℜ𝐦𝒢Λ2𝔰conditionalΛ¯𝐦𝑑𝑚𝑒𝑚𝑑{\mathfrak{R}}_{\mathbf{m}}({\mathscr{G}},\Lambda)\leq\sqrt{2{\mathfrak{s}}(\Lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}})\frac{d}{m}\log\bigg{[}\frac{em}{d}\bigg{]}}.
Proof 4.4.

For any λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda, define the set of vectors Aλsubscript𝐴𝜆A_{\lambda} in ℝmsuperscriptℝ𝑚\mathbb{R}^{m} by

Aλ={[λkmk​ℓ​(h​(xk,i),yk,i)](k,i)∈[p]×[mk]:𝐱∈𝒳m,𝐲∈𝒴m}.subscript𝐴𝜆conditional-setsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘ℓℎsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖𝑘𝑖delimited-[]𝑝delimited-[]subscript𝑚𝑘formulae-sequence𝐱superscript𝒳𝑚𝐲superscript𝒴𝑚A_{\lambda}=\bigg{\{}\bigg{[}\frac{\lambda_{k}}{m_{k}}\ell(h(x_{k,i}),y_{k,i})\bigg{]}_{(k,i)\in[p]\times[m_{k}]}\colon{\mathbf{x}}\in{\mathscr{X}}^{m},{\mathbf{y}}\in{\mathscr{Y}}^{m}\bigg{\}}.

For any 𝐚∈Aλ𝐚subscript𝐴𝜆{\mathbf{a}}\in A_{\lambda}, ‖𝐚‖2=∑k=1pmk​λk2mk2=∑k=1pλk2mk≤𝔰​(Λ∥𝐦¯)msubscriptnorm𝐚2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑘2subscript𝑚𝑘𝔰conditionalΛ¯𝐦𝑚\|{\mathbf{a}}\|_{2}=\sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^{p}m_{k}\frac{\lambda_{k}^{2}}{m_{k}^{2}}}=\sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{\lambda_{k}^{2}}{m_{k}}}\leq\sqrt{\frac{{\mathfrak{s}}(\Lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}})}{m}}. Then, by Massart’s lemma, for any λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda, the following inequalities hold:

ℜ𝐦​(𝒢,λ)subscriptℜ𝐦𝒢𝜆\displaystyle{\mathfrak{R}}_{{\mathbf{m}}}({\mathscr{G}},\lambda) =𝔼Sk∼𝒟kmk𝝈[suph∈ℋ∑k=1pλkmk​∑i=1mkσk,i​ℓ​(h​(xk,i),yk,i)]absentsubscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘𝝈subscriptsupremumℎℋsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑚𝑘subscript𝜎𝑘𝑖ℓℎsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖\displaystyle=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\begin{subarray}{c}S_{k}\sim{\mathscr{D}}_{k}^{m_{k}}\\ {\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\end{subarray}}\left[\sup_{h\in{\mathscr{H}}}\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{\lambda_{k}}{m_{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{m_{k}}\sigma_{k,i}\,\ell(h(x_{k,i}),y_{k,i})\right]
≤𝔼𝝈[sup𝐚∈A∑k=1p∑i=1mkσk,i​ak,i]absentsubscript𝔼𝝈subscriptsupremum𝐚𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑚𝑘subscript𝜎𝑘𝑖subscript𝑎𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}}\left[\sup_{{\mathbf{a}}\in A}\sum_{k=1}^{p}\sum_{i=1}^{m_{k}}\sigma_{k,i}a_{k,i}\right]
≤𝔰​(Λ∥𝐦¯)m​2​log⁡|Aλ|mabsent𝔰conditionalΛ¯𝐦𝑚2subscript𝐴𝜆𝑚\displaystyle\leq\sqrt{\frac{{\mathfrak{s}}(\Lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}})}{m}}\,\frac{\sqrt{2\log|A_{\lambda}|}}{m}
=2​𝔰​(Λ∥𝐦¯)​log⁡|Aλ|m.absent2𝔰conditionalΛ¯𝐦subscript𝐴𝜆𝑚\displaystyle=\frac{\sqrt{2{\mathfrak{s}}(\Lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}})\log|A_{\lambda}|}}{m}.

By Sauer’s lemma, the following holds for m≥d𝑚𝑑m\geq d: |Aλ|≤(e​md)dsubscript𝐴𝜆superscript𝑒𝑚𝑑𝑑|A_{\lambda}|\leq\left(\frac{em}{d}\right)^{d}. Plugging in the right-hand side in the inequality above completes the proof.

Both Lemma 4.3 and the generalization bound of Theorem 4.1 can thus be expressed in terms of the skewness parameter 𝔰​(Λ∥𝐦¯)𝔰conditionalΛ¯𝐦{\mathfrak{s}}(\Lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}}). Note that modulo the skewness parameter, the results look very similar to standard generalization bounds (Mohri et al., 2018). Furthermore, when ΛΛ\Lambda contains only one distribution and is the average distribution, that is λk=mk/msubscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘𝑚\lambda_{k}=m_{k}/m, then the skewness is equal to one and the results coincide with the standard guarantees in supervised learning.

Theorem 4.1 and Lemma 4.3 also provide guidelines for choosing the domains and ΛΛ\Lambda. When p𝑝p is large and Λ=ΔpΛsubscriptΔ𝑝\Lambda=\Delta_{p}, then, the number of samples per domain could be small, the skewness parameter 𝔰​(Λ∥𝐦¯)=max1≤k≤p⁡1mk𝔰conditionalΛ¯𝐦subscript1𝑘𝑝1subscript𝑚𝑘{\mathfrak{s}}(\Lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}})=\max_{1\leq k\leq p}\frac{1}{m_{k}} would then be large and the generalization guarantees for the model would become weaker. We suggest some guidelines for choosing domains in Section 7. We further note that for a given p𝑝p, if ΛΛ\Lambda contains distributions that are close to 𝐦¯¯𝐦\overline{\mathbf{m}}, then the model generalizes well.

The corollary above can be straightforwardly extended to cover the case where the test samples are drawn from some distribution 𝒟𝒟{\mathscr{D}}, instead of 𝒟λsubscript𝒟𝜆{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}. Define ℓ1​(𝒟,𝒟Λ)subscriptℓ1𝒟subscript𝒟Λ\ell_{1}({\mathscr{D}},{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}) by ℓ1​(𝒟,𝒟Λ)=minλ∈Λ⁡ℓ1​(𝒟,𝒟λ)subscriptℓ1𝒟subscript𝒟Λsubscript𝜆Λsubscriptℓ1𝒟subscript𝒟𝜆\ell_{1}({\mathscr{D}},{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda})=\min_{\lambda\in\Lambda}\ell_{1}({\mathscr{D}},{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}). Then, the following result holds.

Corollary 4.5.

Assume that the loss function ℓℓ\ell is bounded by M𝑀M. Then, for any ϵ≥0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\geq 0 and δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, the following inequality holds for all h∈ℋℎℋh\in{\mathscr{H}}:

ℒ𝒟​(h)subscriptℒ𝒟ℎ\displaystyle{\mathscr{L}}_{\mathscr{D}}(h) ≤ℒ𝒟¯Λ​(h)+2​ℜ𝐦​(𝒢,Λ)+M​ℓ1​(𝒟,𝒟Λ)+M​ϵ+M​𝔰​(Λ∥𝐦¯)2​m​log⁡|Λϵ|δ.absentsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟Λℎ2subscriptℜ𝐦𝒢Λ𝑀subscriptℓ1𝒟subscript𝒟Λ𝑀italic-ϵ𝑀𝔰conditionalΛ¯𝐦2𝑚subscriptΛitalic-ϵ𝛿\displaystyle\leq{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h)+2{\mathfrak{R}}_{\mathbf{m}}({\mathscr{G}},\Lambda)+M\ell_{1}({\mathscr{D}},{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda})+M\epsilon+M\sqrt{\frac{{\mathfrak{s}}(\Lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}})}{2m}\log\frac{|\Lambda_{\epsilon}|}{\delta}}.

One straightforward choice of the parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is ϵ=1mitalic-ϵ1𝑚\epsilon=\frac{1}{\sqrt{m}}, but, depending on |Λϵ|subscriptΛitalic-ϵ|\Lambda_{\epsilon}| and other tperms of the bound, more favorable choices may be possible. We conclude this section by adding that alternative learning bounds can be derived for this problem, as discussed in Appendix A.

5 Algorithm

In this section, we introduce a learning algorithm for agnostic federated learning using the guarantees proven in the previous section and discuss in detail an optimization solution.

5.1 Regularization

The learning guarantees of the previous section suggest minimizing the asum of the empirical AFL term ℒ𝒟¯Λ​(h)subscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟Λℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h), a term controlling the complexity of ℋℋ{\mathscr{H}} and a term depending on the skewness parameter. Observe that, since ℒ𝒟¯λ​(h)subscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟𝜆ℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h) is linear in λ𝜆\lambda, the following equality holds:

ℒ𝒟¯Λ​(h)=ℒ𝒟¯conv(Λ)​(h),subscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟Λℎsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟convΛℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}(h)={\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\operatorname*{conv}(\Lambda)}}(h), (5)

where conv(Λ)convΛ\operatorname*{conv}(\Lambda) is the convex hull of ΛΛ\Lambda. Assume that ℋℋ{\mathscr{H}} is a vector space that can be equipped with a norm ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\|, as with most hypothesis sets used in learning applications. Then, given ΛΛ\Lambda and the regularization parameters r≥0𝑟0r\geq 0 and γ≥0𝛾0\gamma\geq 0, our learning guarantees suggest minimizing the regularized loss ℒ𝒟¯Λr​(h)+γ​‖h‖subscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟subscriptΛ𝑟ℎ𝛾normℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda_{r}}}(h)+\gamma\|h\|, where ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| is a suitable norm controlling the complexity of ℋℋ{\mathscr{H}} and where ΛrsubscriptΛ𝑟\Lambda_{r} is defined by Λr={λ∈conv(Λ):1+χ2​(λ∥𝐦¯)≤r}subscriptΛ𝑟conditional-set𝜆convΛ1superscript𝜒2conditional𝜆¯𝐦𝑟\Lambda_{r}=\{\lambda\in\operatorname*{conv}(\Lambda)\colon 1+\chi^{2}(\lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}})\leq r\}. This can be equivalently formulated as the following minimization problem:

minh∈ℋ⁡maxλ∈conv(Λ)⁡ℒ𝒟¯λ​(h)+γ​‖h‖−μ​χ2​(λ∥𝐦¯),subscriptℎℋsubscript𝜆convΛsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟𝜆ℎ𝛾normℎ𝜇superscript𝜒2conditional𝜆¯𝐦\min_{h\in{\mathscr{H}}}\max_{\lambda\in\operatorname*{conv}(\Lambda)}{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)+\gamma\|h\|-\mu\,\chi^{2}(\lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}}), (6)

where μ≥0𝜇0\mu\geq 0 is a hyperparameter. This defines our algorithm for AFL.

Assume that ℓℓ\ell is a convex function of its first argument. Then, ℒ𝒟¯λ​(h)subscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟𝜆ℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h) is a convex function of hℎh. Since ‖h‖normℎ\|h\| is a convex function of hℎh for any choice of the norm, for a fixed λ𝜆\lambda, the objective ℒ𝒟¯λ​(h)+γ​‖h‖−μ​χ2​(λ∥𝐦¯)subscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟𝜆ℎ𝛾normℎ𝜇superscript𝜒2conditional𝜆¯𝐦{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)+\gamma\|h\|-\mu\,\chi^{2}(\lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}}) is a convex function of hℎh. The maximum over λ𝜆\lambda (taken in any set) of a family of convex functions is convex. Thus, maxλ∈conv(Λ)⁡ℒ𝒟¯λ​(h)+γ​‖h‖−μ​χ2​(λ∥𝐦¯)subscript𝜆convΛsubscriptℒsubscript¯𝒟𝜆ℎ𝛾normℎ𝜇superscript𝜒2conditional𝜆¯𝐦\max_{\lambda\in\operatorname*{conv}(\Lambda)}{\mathscr{L}}_{\overline{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}}(h)+\gamma\|h\|-\mu\,\chi^{2}(\lambda\,\|\,\overline{\mathbf{m}}) is a convex function of hℎh and, when the hypothesis set ℋℋ{\mathscr{H}} is a convex, (6) is a convex optimization problem. In the next subsection, we present an efficient optimization solution for this problem, for which we prove convergence guarantees.

5.2 Optimization algorithm

When the loss function ℓℓ\ell is convex, the AFL minmax optimization problem above can be solved using projected gradient descent or other instances of the generic mirror descent algorithm (Nemirovski and Yudin, 1983). However, for large datasets, that is p𝑝p and m𝑚m large, this can be computationally costly and typically slow in practice. Juditsky, Nemirovski, and Tauvel (2011) proposed a stochastic Mirror-Prox algorithm for solving stochastic variational inequalities, which would be applicable in our context. We present a simplified version of their algorithm for the AFL problem that admits a more straightforward analysis and that is also substantially easier to implement.

Our optimization problem is over two sets of parameters, the hypothesis h∈ℋℎℋh\in{\mathscr{H}} and the mixture weight λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda. In what follows, we will denote by w∈𝒲⊂ℝN𝑤𝒲superscriptℝ𝑁w\in{\mathscr{W}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{N} a vector of parameters defining a predictor hℎh and will rewrite losses and optimization solutions only in terms of w𝑤w, instead of hℎh. We will use the following notation:

𝖫​(w,λ)=∑k=1pλk​𝖫k​(w),𝖫𝑤𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝖫𝑘𝑤\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\lambda_{k}\mathsf{L}_{k}(w), (7)

where 𝖫k​(w)subscript𝖫𝑘𝑤\mathsf{L}_{k}(w) stands for ℒ𝒟^k​(h)subscriptℒsubscript^𝒟𝑘ℎ{\mathscr{L}}_{\widehat{\mathscr{D}}_{k}}(h), the empirical loss of hypothesis h∈ℋℎℋh\in{\mathscr{H}} (corresponding to w𝑤w) on domain k𝑘k:

𝖫k​(w)=1mk​∑i=1mkℓ​(h​(xk,i),yk,i).subscript𝖫𝑘𝑤1subscript𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑚𝑘ℓℎsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖\mathsf{L}_{k}(w)=\frac{1}{m_{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{m_{k}}\ell(h(x_{k,i}),y_{k,i}).

Since the regularization terms do not make the optimization problem harder, to simplify the discussion, we will consider the unregularized version of problem (6). Thus, we will study the following problem given by the set of variables w𝑤w:

minw∈𝒲⁡maxλ∈Λ⁡𝖫​(w,λ).subscript𝑤𝒲subscript𝜆Λ𝖫𝑤𝜆\min_{w\in{\mathscr{W}}}\max_{\lambda\in\Lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda). (8)

Observe that problem (8) admits a natural game-theoretic interpretation as a two-player game, where nature selects λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda to maximize the objective, while the learner seeks w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in{\mathscr{W}} minimizing the loss. We are interested in finding the equilibrium of this game, which is attained for some w∗superscript𝑤w^{*}, the minimizer of Equation 8 and λ∗∈Λsuperscript𝜆Λ\lambda^{*}\in\Lambda, the hardest domain mixture weights. At the equilibrium, moving w𝑤w away from w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} or λ𝜆\lambda from λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}, increases the objective function. Hence, λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} can be viewed as the center of ΛΛ\Lambda in the manifold imposed by the loss function 𝖫𝖫\mathsf{L}, whereas 𝒰¯¯𝒰\overline{\mathscr{U}}, the empirical distribution of samples, may lie elsewhere, as illustrated by Figure 2.

By Equation (5), using the set conv(Λ)convΛ\operatorname*{conv}(\Lambda) instead of ΛΛ\Lambda does not affect the solution of the optimization problem. In view of that, in what follows, we will assume, without loss of generality, that ΛΛ\Lambda is a convex set. Observe that, since 𝖫k​(w)subscript𝖫𝑘𝑤\mathsf{L}_{k}(w) is not an average of functions, standard stochastic gradient descent algorithms cannot be used to minimize this objective. We will present instead a new stochastic gradient-type algorithm for this problem.

Let ∇w𝖫​(w,λ)subscript∇𝑤𝖫𝑤𝜆\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda) denote the gradient of the loss function with respect to w𝑤w and ∇λ𝖫​(w,λ)subscript∇𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆\nabla_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda) the gradient with respect to λ𝜆\lambda. Let δw​𝖫​(w,λ)subscript𝛿𝑤𝖫𝑤𝜆\delta_{w}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda), and δλ​𝖫​(w,λ)subscript𝛿𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆\delta_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda) be unbiased estimates of the gradient, that is,

𝔼δ[δλ​𝖫​(w,λ)]=∇λ𝖫​(w,λ)​ and ​𝔼δ[δw​𝖫​(w,λ)]=∇w𝖫​(w,λ).subscript𝔼𝛿subscript𝛿𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆subscript∇𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆 and subscript𝔼𝛿subscript𝛿𝑤𝖫𝑤𝜆subscript∇𝑤𝖫𝑤𝜆\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\delta}[\delta_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)]=\nabla_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)\text{\, and \,}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\delta}[\delta_{w}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)]=\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda).

We first give an optimization algorithm Stochastic-AFL for the AFL problem, assuming access to such unbiased estimates. The pseudocode of the algorithm is given in Figure 3. At each step, the algorithm computes a stochastic gradient with respect to λ𝜆\lambda and w𝑤w and updates the model accordingly. It then projects λ𝜆\lambda to ΛΛ\Lambda by computing a value in ΛΛ\Lambda via convex minimization. If ΛΛ\Lambda is the full simplex, then there is a near-linear time algorithm for this projection Wang and Carreira-Perpinán (2013). It then repeats the process for T𝑇T steps and return the average of the weights. We provide guarantees for this algorithm in terms of the variance of the stochastic gradients when the loss function 𝖫𝖫\mathsf{L} is convex and when the set of w𝑤ws, 𝒲𝒲{\mathscr{W}}, is a compact set.

In the above analysis and in algorithm description in 3, we have ignored the regularization term. If the objective contains a regularization term such as Equation 6, then for λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k}, the regularization term yields a derivative of −2​γ​λk/𝐦¯k2𝛾subscript𝜆𝑘subscript¯𝐦𝑘-2\gamma\lambda_{k}/\overline{\mathbf{m}}_{k}, which can be added to δλ​𝖫​(w,λ)subscript𝛿𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆\delta_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda) in Step 333 in Algorithm 3.

There are several natural candidates for the sampling method defining stochastic gradients. We highlight two techniques: PerDomain gradient and Weighted gradient. We analyze the time complexity and give bounds on the variance for both techniques in Lemmas 5.6 and 5.8 respectively.

Recently, Rakhlin and Sridharan (2013) and Daskalakis et al. (2017) gave an optimistic gradient descent algorithm for minimax optimizations. Our algorithm can also be modified to derive a stochastic optimistic algorithm, which we refer to as Optimistic-Stochastic-AFL. The pseudocode of this algorithm is also given in Figure 3. However, the convergence analysis we present in the next section does not cover this algorithm.

5.3 Analysis

Throughout this section, for simplicity, we adopt the notation introduced for Equation 7. Our convergence guarantees hold under the following assumptions, which are similar to those adopted for the convergence proof of gradient descent-type algorithms.

Properties 1

Assume that the following properties hold for the loss function 𝖫𝖫\mathsf{L} and sets 𝒲𝒲{\mathscr{W}} and Λ⊆ΔpΛsubscriptΔ𝑝\Lambda\subseteq\Delta_{p}:

  1. 1.

    Convexity: w↦𝖫​(w,λ)maps-to𝑤𝖫𝑤𝜆w\mapsto\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda) is convex for any λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda.

  2. 2.

    Compactness: maxλ∈Λ⁡‖λ‖2≤RΛsubscript𝜆Λsubscriptnorm𝜆2subscript𝑅Λ\max_{\lambda\in\Lambda}\|\lambda\|_{2}\leq R_{\Lambda} and maxw∈𝒲⁡‖w‖2≤R𝒲subscript𝑤𝒲subscriptnorm𝑤2subscript𝑅𝒲\max_{w\in{\mathscr{W}}}\|w\|_{2}\leq R_{{\mathscr{W}}}, for some RΛ>0subscript𝑅Λ0R_{\Lambda}>0 and R𝒲>0subscript𝑅𝒲0R_{{\mathscr{W}}}>0.

  3. 3.

    Bounded gradients: ‖∇w𝖫​(w,λ)‖2≤Gwsubscriptnormsubscript∇𝑤𝖫𝑤𝜆2subscript𝐺𝑤\|\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)\|_{2}\leq G_{w} and ‖∇λ𝖫​(w,λ)‖2≤Gλsubscriptnormsubscript∇𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆2subscript𝐺𝜆\|\nabla_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)\|_{2}\leq G_{\lambda} for all w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in{\mathscr{W}} and λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda.

  4. 4.

    Stochastic variance: 𝔼[‖δw​𝖫​(w,λ)−∇w𝖫​(w,λ)‖22]≤σw2𝔼superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝛿𝑤𝖫𝑤𝜆subscript∇𝑤𝖫𝑤𝜆22subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑤\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[\|\delta_{w}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)-\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)\|_{2}^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2}_{w} and 𝔼[‖δλ​𝖫​(w,λ)−∇λ𝖫​(w,λ)‖22]≤σλ2𝔼superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝛿𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆subscript∇𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆22subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝜆\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[\|\delta_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)-\nabla_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)\|_{2}^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2}_{\lambda} for all w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in{\mathscr{W}} and λ∈λ𝜆𝜆\lambda\in\lambda.

  5. 5.

    Time complexity: Uwsubscript𝑈𝑤U_{w} denotes the time complexity of computing δw​𝖫​(w,λ)subscript𝛿𝑤𝖫𝑤𝜆\delta_{w}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda), Uλsubscript𝑈𝜆U_{\lambda} that of computing δλ​𝖫​(w,λ)subscript𝛿𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆\delta_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda), Upsubscript𝑈𝑝U_{p} that of the projection, and d𝑑d denotes the dimensionality of 𝒲𝒲{\mathscr{W}}.

Theorem 5.1.

Assume that the Properties 1 hold. Then, for the steps sizes γw=2​R𝒲T​(σw2+Gw2)subscript𝛾𝑤2subscript𝑅𝒲𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝐺2𝑤\gamma_{w}=\frac{2R_{{\mathscr{W}}}}{\sqrt{T(\sigma^{2}_{w}+G^{2}_{w})}} and γλ=2​RΛT​(σλ2+Gλ2)subscript𝛾𝜆2subscript𝑅Λ𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝐺2𝜆\gamma_{\lambda}=\frac{2R_{\Lambda}}{\sqrt{T(\sigma^{2}_{\lambda}+G^{2}_{\lambda})}}, the following guarantee holds for Stochastic-AFL:

𝔼[maxλ∈Λ⁡𝖫​(wA,λ)−minw∈𝒲⁡maxλ∈Λ⁡𝖫​(w,λ)]≤3​R𝒲​(σw2+Gw2)T+3​RΛ​(σλ2+Gλ2)T.𝔼subscript𝜆Λ𝖫superscript𝑤𝐴𝜆subscript𝑤𝒲subscript𝜆Λ𝖫𝑤𝜆3subscript𝑅𝒲subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝐺2𝑤𝑇3subscript𝑅Λsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝐺2𝜆𝑇\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}\left[\max_{\lambda\in\Lambda}\mathsf{L}(w^{A},\lambda)-\min_{w\in{\mathscr{W}}}\max_{\lambda\in\Lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)\right]\leq\frac{3R_{{\mathscr{W}}}\sqrt{(\sigma^{2}_{w}+G^{2}_{w})}}{\sqrt{T}}+\frac{3R_{\Lambda}\sqrt{(\sigma^{2}_{\lambda}+G^{2}_{\lambda})}}{\sqrt{T}}.

and the time complexity of the algorithm is in 𝒪​((Uλ+Uw+Up+d+k)​T)𝒪subscript𝑈𝜆subscript𝑈𝑤subscript𝑈𝑝𝑑𝑘𝑇\mathcal{O}((U_{\lambda}+U_{w}+U_{p}+d+k)T).

5.4 Stochastic gradients

The convergence results of Theorem 5.1 depend on the variance of the stochastic gradients. Thus, before proceeding to the results, we first compute the gradients with respect to w𝑤w and λ𝜆\lambda. Let 𝖫k,i​(w)=ℓ​(h​(xk,i,yk,i))subscript𝖫𝑘𝑖𝑤ℓℎsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖\mathsf{L}_{k,i}(w)=\ell(h(x_{k,i},y_{k,i})). For any w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in{\mathscr{W}}, λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda and k∈[p]𝑘delimited-[]𝑝k\in[p], the gradient with respect to w𝑤w is given by

∇w𝖫​(w,λ)=∑k=1pλkmk​∑i=1mk∇w𝖫k,i​(w).subscript∇𝑤𝖫𝑤𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘𝑖1subscript∇𝑤subscript𝖫𝑘𝑖𝑤\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{\lambda_{k}}{m_{k}}\sum^{m_{k}}_{i=1}\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}_{k,i}(w).

For any w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in{\mathscr{W}}, λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda and k∈[p]𝑘delimited-[]𝑝k\in[p], the gradient with respect to λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k} is given by

[∇λ𝖫​(w,λ)]k=1mk​∑i=1mk𝖫k,i​(w)=𝖫k​(w).subscriptdelimited-[]subscript∇𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆𝑘1subscript𝑚𝑘subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘𝑖1subscript𝖫𝑘𝑖𝑤subscript𝖫𝑘𝑤[\nabla_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)]_{k}=\frac{1}{m_{k}}\sum^{m_{k}}_{i=1}\mathsf{L}_{k,i}(w)=\mathsf{L}_{k}(w).

We first discuss the stochastic gradients for λ𝜆\lambda. Notice that the gradient for λ𝜆\lambda is independent of λ𝜆\lambda. Thus, a natural choice for the stochastic gradient with respect to λ𝜆\lambda is based on uniformly sampling a domain K∈[p]𝐾delimited-[]𝑝K\in[p] and then sampling xK,isubscript𝑥𝐾𝑖x_{K,i} from domain K𝐾K. This leads to the definition of the stochastic gradient δλ​𝖫​(w,λ)subscript𝛿𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆\delta_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda) shown in Figure 4. The following lemma bounds the variance for that definition of δλ​𝖫​(w,λ)subscript𝛿𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆\delta_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda).

Lemma 5.3.

The stochastic gradient δλ​𝖫​(w,λ)subscript𝛿𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆\delta_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda) is unbiased. Further, if the loss function is bounded by M𝑀M, then the following upper bound holds for the variance of δλ​𝖫​(w,λ)subscript𝛿𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆\delta_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda):

σλ2=maxw∈𝒲,λ∈Λ​Var(δλ​𝖫​(w,λ))≤p2​M2.subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝜆subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤𝒲𝜆ΛVarsubscript𝛿𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆superscript𝑝2superscript𝑀2\sigma^{2}_{\lambda}=\max_{w\in{\mathscr{W}},\lambda\in\Lambda}\operatorname*{Var}(\delta_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda))\leq p^{2}M^{2}.
Proof 5.4.

The unbiasedness of δλ​𝖫​(w,λ)subscript𝛿𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆\delta_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda) follows directly its definition. For the variance, observe that, for index k∈[p]𝑘delimited-[]𝑝k\in[p], since the probability of not drawing domain k𝑘k is (1−1p)11𝑝(1-\frac{1}{p}), the variance is given by the following

Vark[δλ​𝖫​(w,λ)]subscriptVar𝑘subscript𝛿𝜆𝖫𝑤𝜆\displaystyle\operatorname*{Var}_{k}[\delta_{\lambda}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)] =[1−1p]​[0−𝖫k​(w)]2+1p​∑k=1p1mk​∑i=1mk[p​𝖫k,i​(w)−𝖫k​(w)]2absentdelimited-[]11𝑝superscriptdelimited-[]0subscript𝖫𝑘𝑤21𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝1subscript𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑚𝑘superscriptdelimited-[]𝑝subscript𝖫𝑘𝑖𝑤subscript𝖫𝑘𝑤2\displaystyle=\bigg{[}1-\frac{1}{p}\bigg{]}[0-\mathsf{L}_{k}(w)]^{2}+\frac{1}{p}\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{1}{m_{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{m_{k}}\left[p\mathsf{L}_{k,i}(w)-\mathsf{L}_{k}(w)\right]^{2}
≤[1−1p]​M2+1p​∑k=1p1mk​∑i=1mk[p​M]2=p​M2.absentdelimited-[]11𝑝superscript𝑀21𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝1subscript𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑚𝑘superscriptdelimited-[]𝑝𝑀2𝑝superscript𝑀2\displaystyle\leq\bigg{[}1-\frac{1}{p}\bigg{]}M^{2}+\frac{1}{p}\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{1}{m_{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{m_{k}}[pM]^{2}=pM^{2}.

Summing over all indices from k∈[p]𝑘delimited-[]𝑝k\in[p] completes the proof.

If the above variance is too high, then we can sample one Jksubscript𝐽𝑘J_{k} for every domain k𝑘k. This is same as computing the gradient of a batch and reduces the variance by a factor of p𝑝p.

The gradient with respect to w𝑤w depends both on λ𝜆\lambda and w𝑤w. There are two natural stochastic gradients: the PerDomain-stochastic gradient and the Weighted-stochastic gradient. For a PerDomain-stochastic gradient, we sample an element uniformly from [mk]delimited-[]subscript𝑚𝑘[m_{k}] for each k∈[p]𝑘delimited-[]𝑝k\in[p]. For the Weighted-stochastic gradient, we sample a domain according to λ𝜆\lambda and sample an element out of it. To bound the variance of these two stochastic gradients, we need a few definitions.

Definition 5.5.

The following definitions are used:

  • •

    the intra-domain variance with respect to w𝑤w is defined as follows:

    σI2​(w)=maxw∈𝒲,k∈[p]⁡1mk​∑j=1mk[∇wLk,j​(w)−∇wLk​(w)]2.subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐼𝑤subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤𝒲𝑘delimited-[]𝑝1subscript𝑚𝑘subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘𝑗1superscriptdelimited-[]subscript∇𝑤subscript𝐿𝑘𝑗𝑤subscript∇𝑤subscript𝐿𝑘𝑤2\sigma^{2}_{I}(w)=\max_{w\in{\mathscr{W}},k\in[p]}\frac{1}{m_{k}}\sum^{m_{k}}_{j=1}\left[\nabla_{w}L_{k,j}(w)-\nabla_{w}L_{k}(w)\right]^{2}.
  • •

    the outer-domain variance with respect to w𝑤w is defined as follows:

    σO2​(w)=maxw∈𝒲,λ∈Λ​∑k=1pλk​[∇w𝖫k​(w)−∇w𝖫​(w,λ)]2.subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑂𝑤subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤𝒲𝜆Λsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘1subscript𝜆𝑘superscriptdelimited-[]subscript∇𝑤subscript𝖫𝑘𝑤subscript∇𝑤𝖫𝑤𝜆2\sigma^{2}_{O}(w)=\max_{w\in{\mathscr{W}},\lambda\in\Lambda}\sum^{p}_{k=1}\lambda_{k}\left[\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}_{k}(w)-\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)\right]^{2}.
  • •

    the time complexity of computing the loss and gradient with respect to w𝑤w for a single sample is denoted by U𝑈U.

With these definitions, we can bound the variance of both PerDomain and Weighted stochastic gradients.

Lemma 5.6.

PerDomain stochastic gradient is unbiased and runs in time p​U+𝒪​(p​log⁡m)𝑝𝑈𝒪𝑝𝑚pU+\mathcal{O}(p\log m) and the variance satisfy,

σw2≤RΛ​σI2​(w).subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑤subscript𝑅Λsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐼𝑤\sigma^{2}_{w}\leq R_{\Lambda}\sigma^{2}_{I}(w).
Proof 5.7.

The time complexity and the unbiasedness follow from the definitions. We now bound the variance. Since ∇w𝖫k,Jksubscript∇𝑤subscript𝖫𝑘subscript𝐽𝑘\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}_{k,J_{k}} is an unbiased estimate of ∇w𝖫k​(w)subscript∇𝑤subscript𝖫𝑘𝑤\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}_{k}(w) and we have:

Var[δw]=∑k=1pλk2​Var[∇w𝖫k,Jk​(w)−∇w𝖫k​(w)]≤∑k=1pλk2​σ2​(w,I)≤RΛ​σI2​(w).Varsubscript𝛿𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝜆2𝑘Varsubscript∇𝑤subscript𝖫𝑘subscript𝐽𝑘𝑤subscript∇𝑤subscript𝖫𝑘𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝜆2𝑘superscript𝜎2𝑤𝐼subscript𝑅Λsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐼𝑤\displaystyle\operatorname*{Var}[\delta_{w}]=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\lambda^{2}_{k}\operatorname*{Var}\left[\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}_{k,J_{k}}(w)-\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}_{k}(w)\right]\leq\sum_{k=1}^{p}\lambda^{2}_{k}\sigma^{2}(w,I)\leq R_{\Lambda}\sigma^{2}_{I}(w).

This completes the proof.

Lemma 5.8.

Weighted stochastic gradient is unbiased and runs in time U+𝒪​(k+log⁡n)𝑈𝒪𝑘𝑛U+\mathcal{O}(k+\log n) and the variance satisfy the following inequality:

σw2≤σI2​(w)+σO2​(w).subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐼𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑂𝑤\sigma^{2}_{w}\leq\sigma^{2}_{I}(w)+\sigma^{2}_{O}(w).
Proof 5.9.

The time complexity and the unbiasedness follow from the definitions. We now bound the variance. By definition for any w,λ𝑤𝜆w,\lambda,

Var(δw)Varsubscript𝛿𝑤\displaystyle\operatorname*{Var}(\delta_{w}) =∑k=1pλkmk​∑j=1mk(∇w𝖫k,j​(w)−𝖫​(w,λ))2absentsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘1subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘𝑗1superscriptsubscript∇𝑤subscript𝖫𝑘𝑗𝑤𝖫𝑤𝜆2\displaystyle=\sum^{p}_{k=1}\frac{\lambda_{k}}{m_{k}}\sum^{m_{k}}_{j=1}\left(\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}_{k,j}(w)-\mathsf{L}(w,\lambda)\right)^{2}
=∑k=1pλkmk​∑j=1mk(∇w𝖫k,j​(w)−𝖫k​(w))2+∑k=1pλk​(𝖫k​(w)−𝖫​(w,h))2absentsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘1subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘𝑗1superscriptsubscript∇𝑤subscript𝖫𝑘𝑗𝑤subscript𝖫𝑘𝑤2subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘1subscript𝜆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝖫𝑘𝑤𝖫𝑤ℎ2\displaystyle=\sum^{p}_{k=1}\frac{\lambda_{k}}{m_{k}}\sum^{m_{k}}_{j=1}\left(\nabla_{w}\mathsf{L}_{k,j}(w)-\mathsf{L}_{k}(w)\right)^{2}+\sum^{p}_{k=1}\lambda_{k}(\mathsf{L}_{k}(w)-\mathsf{L}(w,h))^{2}
≤σI2​(w)+σO2​(w),absentsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐼𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑂𝑤\displaystyle\leq\sigma^{2}_{I}(w)+\sigma^{2}_{O}(w),

where the second equality follows from the unbiasedness of the stochastic gradients.

Since RΛ≤1subscript𝑅Λ1R_{\Lambda}\leq 1, at first glance, the above two lemmas may suggest that PerDomain stochastic is always better than Weighted stochastic gradient. Note, however, that the time complexities of the algorithms is dominated by U𝑈U and thus, the time complexity of PerDomain-stochastic gradient is roughly k𝑘k times larger than that of Weighted-stochastic gradient. Hence, if k𝑘k is small, it is preferable to choose the PerDomain-stochastic gradient.

For large values of p𝑝p, to do a fair comparison, we need to average p𝑝p independent copies of the Weighted-stochastic gradient, which we refer to as p𝑝p-Weighted, and compare it with the PerDomain-stochastic gradient. Since the variance of average of p𝑝p i.i.d. random variables is 1/p1𝑝1/p times the individual variance, by Lemma 5.8, the following holds:

Var(k-Weighted)=σI2​(w)+σO2​(w)p.Vark-Weightedsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐼𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑂𝑤𝑝\operatorname*{Var}(\textsc{$k$-Weighted})=\frac{\sigma^{2}_{I}(w)+\sigma^{2}_{O}(w)}{p}.

Further, observe that RΛ=maxλ∈Λ​∑k=1pλk2≥1psubscript𝑅Λsubscript𝜆Λsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘1subscriptsuperscript𝜆2𝑘1𝑝R_{\Lambda}=\max_{\lambda\in\Lambda}\sum^{p}_{k=1}\lambda^{2}_{k}\geq\frac{1}{p}. Thus,

Var(PerDomain)≥σI2​(w)p.VarPerDomainsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐼𝑤𝑝\operatorname*{Var}(\textsc{PerDomain})\geq\frac{\sigma^{2}_{I}(w)}{p}.

Hence, the right choice of the stochastic variance of w𝑤w depends on the application. If all domains are roughly equally weighted, then we have R​(Λ)≈1p𝑅Λ1𝑝R(\Lambda)\approx\frac{1}{p} and the PerDomain-variance is a more favorable choice. Otherwise, if σO2​(w)subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑂𝑤\sigma^{2}_{O}(w) is small, then the Weighted-stochastic gradient is more favorable.

6 Experiments

To study the benefits of our AFL algorithm, we carried out experiments with three datasets. Even though our optimization convergence guarantees hold only for convex functions and stochastic gradient, we show that our domain-agnostic learning performs well for non-convex functions and variants of stochastic gradient descent such as momentum and Adagrad too.

In all the three experiments, we compare the domain agnostic model with the model trained with 𝒰^^𝒰\widehat{\mathscr{U}}, the uniform distribution over the union of samples, and the models trained on individual domains. In all of these experiments, we used PerDomain stochastic gradients and set Λ=ΔpΛsubscriptΔ𝑝\Lambda=\Delta_{p}. All algorithms were implemented in Tensorflow (Abadi et al., 2015).

6.1 Adult dataset

The Adult dataset is a census dataset from the UCI Machine Learning Repository (Blake, 1998). It contains 32,5613256132\mathord{,}561 training samples with numerical and categorical features, each representing a person. The task consists of predicting if the person’s income exceeds $50,000currency-dollar50000\$50\mathord{,}000. We split this dataset into two domains depending on whether the person had a doctorate degree or not, resulting into domains: the doctorate domain containing 413413413 examples and the non-doctorate domain containing 32,1483214832\mathord{,}148 examples. We trained a logistic regression model with just the categorical features and Adagrad optimizer. The performance of the models averaged over 505050 runs is reported in Table 1. The performance on 𝒟Λsubscript𝒟Λ{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda} of the model trained with 𝒰^^𝒰\widehat{\mathscr{U}}, that is standard federated learning, is about 69.6%percent69.669.6\%. In contrast, the performance of our AFL model is at least about 71.5%percent71.571.5\% on any target distribution 𝒟λsubscript𝒟𝜆{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}. The uniform average over the domains of the test accuracy of the AFL model is slightly less than that of the uniform model, but the agnostic model is less biased and performs better on 𝒟Λsubscript𝒟Λ{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}. Furthermore, of the two domains, the doctorate domain is the harder one for predictions. For this domain, the performance of the domain agnostic model is close to the model trained only on doctorate data and is better than that of the model trained with the uniform distribution 𝒰^^𝒰\widehat{\mathscr{U}}.

6.2 Fashion MNIST

The Fashion MNIST dataset, originally announced by Xiao et al. (2017), is an MNIST-like dataset where images are classified into 101010 categories of clothing, instead of handwritten digits. The dataset includes 60,0006000060\mathord{,}000 training images and 10,0001000010\mathord{,}000 test images given as 28x28 arrays of grayscale pixel intensities, spread evenly among the ten categories. We first trained a simple logistic regression classifier and observed that the lowest performance was achieved for the following three categories: t-shirt/top, pullover, and shirt. Next, we extracted the subset of the data labeled with these three categories and split this subset into three domains, each consisting of one class of clothing. We then trained a classifier for the three classes using logistic regression and the Adam optimizer. The results are shown in Table 2. Since here the domain uniquely identifies the label, in this experiment, we did not compare against models trained on specific domains. Of the three domains or classes, the shirt class is the hardest one to distinguish from others. The domain-agnostic model improves the performance for shirt more than it degrades it on pullover and shirt, leading to both shirt-specific and overall accuracy improvement when compared to the model trained with the uniform distribution 𝒰^^𝒰\widehat{\mathscr{U}}. Furthermore, in this experiment, note that our agnostic learning solution not only improves the loss of the worst domain, but also generalizes better and hence improves the average test accuracy. Our AFL model achieves a performance of about %74.5\%74.5 on any target distribution 𝒟λsubscript𝒟𝜆{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda}, while the performance of standard federated learning can be as low as about %71.2\%71.2.

6.3 Language models

Motivated by the keyboard application (Hard et al., 2018), where a single client uses a trained language model in multiple environments such as chat apps, email, and web input, we created a dataset that combines two very different types of language datasets: conversation and document. For conversation, we used the Cornell movie dataset that contain movie dialogues Danescu-Niculescu-Mizil and Lee (2011). This dataset contains about 300,000300000300\mathord{,}000 sentences with an average sentence length of 888. For documents, we used the Penn TreeBank (PTB) dataset that contains approximately 50,0005000050\mathord{,}000 sentences with an average sentence length of 202020 Marcus et al. (1993). We created a single dataset by combining both of the above corpuses, with conversation and document as domains. We preprocessed the data to remove punctuations, capitalized the data uniformly, and computed a vocabulary of 10,0001000010\mathord{,}000 most frequent words. We trained a two-layer LSTM model with LSTM and projection size of 512512512 with momentum optimizer. The performance of the models are measured by their perplexity, that is the exponent of cross-entropy loss. The results are reported in Table 3. Of the two domains, the document domain is the one admitting the higher perplexity. For this domain, the test perplexity of the domain agnostic model is close to that of the model trained only on document data and is better than that of the model trained with the uniform distribution 𝒰^^𝒰\widehat{\mathscr{U}}.

7 Extensions

In this section, we briefly discuss several extensions of the framework, theory and algorithms that we presented.

7.1 Domain definitions

The choice of the domains can significantly impact learnability in federated learning. In view of our learning bounds, if the number of domains, p𝑝p, is large and ΛΛ\Lambda is the full simplex, Λ=ΔpΛsubscriptΔ𝑝\Lambda=\Delta_{p}, then the models may not generalize well. Thus, if the number of clients is very large, using each client as a domain may be a poor choice for better generalization. Ideally, each domain is represented with a sufficiently large number of samples and is relatively homogeneous or pure. This suggests using a clustering algorithm for defining the domains based on the similarity of the client distributions. Different Bregman divergences could be used to define the divergence or similarity between distributions. Thus, techniques such as those of Banerjee, Merugu, Dhillon, and Ghosh (2005) could be used to determine clusters of clients using a suitable Bregman divergence.

Client clusters can also be determined based on domain expertise. For example, in federated keyboard next word prediction (Hard et al., 2018), domains can be chosen to be the native language of the clients. If the model is used in variety of applications, domains can also be based on the application of interest. For example, the keyboard in (Hard et al., 2018) is used in chat apps, social apps, and web inputs. Here, domains can be the app that was used. Training models agnostically ensures that the user experience is favorable in all apps.

7.2 Incorporating a prior on ΛΛ\Lambda

Agnostic federated learning as defined in (1) treats all domains equally and does not incorporate any prior knowledge of λ𝜆\lambda. Suppose we have a prior distribution pΛ​(λ)subscript𝑝Λ𝜆p_{\Lambda}(\lambda) over λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda at our disposal, then, we can modify (1) to incorporate that prior. If the loss function ℓℓ\ell is the cross-entropy loss, then the agnostic loss can be modified as follows:

maxλ∈Λ⁡(ℒDλ​(h)+log⁡pΛ​(λ)).subscript𝜆Λsubscriptℒsubscript𝐷𝜆ℎsubscript𝑝Λ𝜆\max_{\lambda\in\Lambda}\left({\mathscr{L}}_{D_{\lambda}}(h)+\log p_{\Lambda}(\lambda)\right). (9)

In this formulation, larger weights are assigned to more likely domains. The generalization guarantees of Theorem 4.1 can be appropriately modified to include these changes. Furthermore, if the prior pΛ​(λ)subscript𝑝Λ𝜆p_{\Lambda}(\lambda) is a log-concave function of λ𝜆\lambda, then the new objective is convex in hℎh and concave in λ𝜆\lambda and a slight modification of our proposed algorithm can be used to determine the global minima. We note that we could also adopt a multiplicative formulation with the prior multiplying the loss, instead of the additive one with the negative log of the probability in Equation 9.

7.3 Domain features and personalization

We studied agnostic federated learning, where we learn a model that performs well on all domains. First, notice that we do not make any assumption on the hypothesis set ℋℋ{\mathscr{H}} and the hypotheses can use the domain k𝑘k as a feature. Such models could be useful for applications where the target domain is known at inference time. Second, while the paper deals with learning a centralized model, the resulting model h𝒟Λsubscriptℎsubscript𝒟Λh_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}} can be combined with a personalized model, on the client’s machine, to design better client-specific models. This can be done for example by learning an appropriate mixture weight αk∈[0,1]subscript𝛼𝑘01\alpha_{k}\in[0,1] to use a mixture αk​h𝒟Λ+(1−αk)​hksubscript𝛼𝑘subscriptℎsubscript𝒟Λ1subscript𝛼𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘\alpha_{k}h_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}}+(1-\alpha_{k})h_{k} of the domain agnostic centralized model h𝒟Λsubscriptℎsubscript𝒟Λh_{{\mathscr{D}}_{\Lambda}} and a client- or domain-specific model hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k}.

8 Conclusion

We introduced a new framework of AFL for which we presented a detailed theoretical analysis. We also gave an algorithm for this problem benefiting from our theoretical analysis, as well as a new stochastic optimization solution needed for large-scale problems. Our experimental results suggest that our solution can lead to significant benefits in practice.

  • Woodworth et al. (2018) Blake E. Woodworth, Jialei Wang, Adam D. Smith, Brendan McMahan, and Nati Srebro. Graph oracle models, lower bounds, and gaps for parallel stochastic optimization. In Proceedings of NeurIPS, pages 8505–8515, 2018.
  • Xiao et al. (2017) Han Xiao, Kashif Rasul, and Roland Vollgraf. Fashion-MNIST: a novel image dataset for benchmarking machine learning algorithms. CoRR, abs/1708.07747, 2017. URL http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.07747.
  • Xu et al. (2014) Zheng Xu, Wen Li, Li Niu, and Dong Xu. Exploiting low-rank structure from latent domains for domain generalization. In ECCV, volume 8691, pages 628–643, 2014.
  • Yang et al. (2007) Jun Yang, Rong Yan, and Alexander G. Hauptmann. Cross-domain video concept detection using adaptive svms. In ACM Multimedia, pages 188–197, 2007.
  • Zhang et al. (2015) Kun Zhang, Mingming Gong, and Bernhard Schölkopf. Multi-source domain adaptation: A causal view. In AAAI, pages 3150–3157, 2015.

Appendix A Alternative learning guarantees

An objective similar to that of AFL was considered in the context of multiple source domain adaptation by Liu et al. (2015). The authors presented generalization bounds for a scenario where the target is based on some specific mixture λ𝜆\lambda of the source domains. Our theoretical results differ from those of this work in two ways. First, our generalization bounds do not hold for a single mixture weight λ𝜆\lambda but for any subset ΛΛ\Lambda of the simplex. Second, the complexity terms in the bounds presented by these authors are proportional to m​maxk∈[p]⁡λkmk𝑚subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝑝subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘\sqrt{m}\max_{k\in[p]}\frac{\lambda_{k}}{m_{k}}, while our guarantees are in terms of ∑k=1pλk2mksuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝜆2𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘\sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^{p}\frac{\lambda^{2}_{k}}{m_{k}}}, which is strictly tighter. In particular, in the special case where k=2𝑘2k=2, λ1=1msubscript𝜆11𝑚\lambda_{1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{m}}, λ2=1−λ1subscript𝜆21subscript𝜆1\lambda_{2}=1-\lambda_{1} and m1=1subscript𝑚11m_{1}=1 and m2=m−1subscript𝑚2𝑚1m_{2}=m-1, the bounds of Liu et al. (2015) are proportional to a constant and thus not informative, m​maxk∈[p]⁡λkmk=1𝑚subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝑝subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘1\sqrt{m}\max_{k\in[p]}\frac{\lambda_{k}}{m_{k}}=1, while our guarantees are in terms of 1m1𝑚\frac{1}{\sqrt{m}}.

Our generalization error in Theorem 4.1 is particularly useful when ΛΛ\Lambda is a strict subset of the simple, Λ⊂ΔpΛsubscriptΔ𝑝\Lambda\subset\Delta_{p}. If Λ=ΔpΛsubscriptΔ𝑝\Lambda=\Delta_{p}, we can give the following alternative learning guarantee based.

Hence, up to the logarithmic factors in the second term, the guarantee of Theorem 4.1 is stronger than that of Theorem A.1. However, ΛϵsubscriptΛitalic-ϵ\Lambda_{\epsilon} can be large and exponential in p𝑝p, and it is not clear which of the bounds are stronger in general. This depends on 𝐦¯¯𝐦\overline{\mathbf{m}} and λ𝜆\lambda. Deriving learning bounds that improve upon both of the learning bounds above remains an interesting open question.
